componenttext: [Operator Instructions] And we'll take our first question from Entcho Raykovski with Deutsche Bank.

headline: News Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: My question's around Foxtel, we're obviously getting revenue growth, but there has been a significant step-up in the costs. How do you think about those costs going forward? Do you view the costs now providing effectively a base? Or is there -- are there
componenttext: My question's around Foxtel, we're obviously getting revenue growth, but there has been a significant step-up in the costs. How do you think about those costs going forward? Do you view the costs now providing effectively a base? Or is there -- are there some one-off costs in this quarter which you'll likely just cycle out of -- in subsequent quarters?

headline: News Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: In the quarter, obviously, some of the costs were related to programming, so we had costs for the motor sports. And so I think, those, to the extent we have sports-related costs, you'd expect them to recur. In terms of marketing costs, we're still activel
componenttext: In the quarter, obviously, some of the costs were related to programming, so we had costs for the motor sports. And so I think, those, to the extent we have sports-related costs, you'd expect them to recur. In terms of marketing costs, we're still actively marketing the new packages, and I think there will be some continuing costs for that, but we should see those tapering down in the second half of the year. Obviously, with triple play, there'll be customer support and installation costs that will continue. But then we should see those tapering down.

headline: News Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Entcho, to add to Bedi's answer. Obviously, sales in Q1 were up 38%. Total subs are up 10% to 2.9 million. It's a very dynamic market in Australia at the moment, as you're well aware. There is some competition, for example, from Netflix. But what you have
componenttext: Entcho, to add to Bedi's answer. Obviously, sales in Q1 were up 38%. Total subs are up 10% to 2.9 million. It's a very dynamic market in Australia at the moment, as you're well aware. There is some competition, for example, from Netflix. But what you have to realize is the offering at Netflix is certainly inferior to that of Foxtel, and indeed inferior to that of Netflix in the U.S.

headline: News Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: And just to add to that, obviously, the full impact of the new subscribers that we've added hasn't yet flowed through because the additions were in the second half of last fiscal year. So you should see that flowing through as well, as the year goes on.
componenttext: And just to add to that, obviously, the full impact of the new subscribers that we've added hasn't yet flowed through because the additions were in the second half of last fiscal year. So you should see that flowing through as well, as the year goes on.

headline: News Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: And we'll take our next question from Fraser McLeish with Credit Suisse.
componenttext: And we'll take our next question from Fraser McLeish with Credit Suisse.

headline: News Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: I've got a Foxtel-related question as well. Just quickly, I think you -- at the full year, you had said you expected Foxtel EBITDA to grow in FY '16. I'm just wondering if you're still expecting that given the first quarter. And also, it was helpful break
componenttext: I've got a Foxtel-related question as well. Just quickly, I think you -- at the full year, you had said you expected Foxtel EBITDA to grow in FY '16. I'm just wondering if you're still expecting that given the first quarter. And also, it was helpful breaking out the cable and satellite growth. But I was just wondering, are you able to give us the number of Presto subscribers that are actually included in that base.

headline: News Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think we still expect Foxtel to show EBITDA improvement as the year goes on. And again, it's a factor of what Robert and I both mentioned in response to the previous question, which is, you'll see the effect of revenues for the new subscribers going all
componenttext: I think we still expect Foxtel to show EBITDA improvement as the year goes on. And again, it's a factor of what Robert and I both mentioned in response to the previous question, which is, you'll see the effect of revenues for the new subscribers going all the way through and some tapering down of the costs. We're not actually breaking out, I think, the Presto numbers. But needless to say, most of the growth that we saw came from cable and satellite subscribers.

headline: News Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: We'll take our next question from Alice Bennett with CBA.
componenttext: We'll take our next question from Alice Bennett with CBA.

headline: News Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: I'm sorry, I've got another Foxtel question. I just was wondering if you could give us a sense where ARPU has come to, relative to the $93 you talked about in FY '15. But also just a sense of whether you're seeing any stabilization from the pricing cut, b
componenttext: I'm sorry, I've got another Foxtel question. I just was wondering if you could give us a sense where ARPU has come to, relative to the $93 you talked about in FY '15. But also just a sense of whether you're seeing any stabilization from the pricing cut, but also presumably some tiering down as Netflix penetration picks up in Australia. Just whether you're seeing those ARPU numbers start to base out or you think there's still further downside to come.

headline: News Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: So I think with the new pricing packages, what we're seeing is that ARPU has come down a little, I would say, sort of mid-single digits. We haven't actually given out the actual ARPU number. But what's happening, I think, with that is we're seeing churn h
componenttext: So I think with the new pricing packages, what we're seeing is that ARPU has come down a little, I would say, sort of mid-single digits. We haven't actually given out the actual ARPU number. But what's happening, I think, with that is we're seeing churn has actually improved. And in terms of spin-down, I think it's sort of on plan is the best way to put it. So we haven't seen anything significantly worrying with respect to spin-down.

headline: News Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just to supplement Bedi on the point of churn, it's down from 10.5% to 10.1%. Obviously, it's a very competitive market, but we believe we have a very competitive product.
componenttext: Just to supplement Bedi on the point of churn, it's down from 10.5% to 10.1%. Obviously, it's a very competitive market, but we believe we have a very competitive product.

headline: News Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: We'll take our next question from Alexia Quadrani with JPMorgan.
componenttext: We'll take our next question from Alexia Quadrani with JPMorgan.

headline: News Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: This is for James Kopelman in for Alexia. I just wanted to ask about the journal in video and mobile advertising. I'm just curious how -- if you can provide any insight on how mobile and video are progressing. And particularly given how rapidly mobile's g
componenttext: This is for James Kopelman in for Alexia. I just wanted to ask about the journal in video and mobile advertising. I'm just curious how -- if you can provide any insight on how mobile and video are progressing. And particularly given how rapidly mobile's growing at a couple of your peers, could you say anything about adding new marketers maybe that are already advertising in other platforms that you might be bringing on to mobile for the first time?

headline: News Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: It's a very good question. We are seeing obviously, significant growth in the mobile audience. And generally speaking, in recent years, that growth in audience hasn't been reflected in a similar growth in mobile advertising. What we've done by acquiring c
componenttext: It's a very good question. We are seeing obviously, significant growth in the mobile audience. And generally speaking, in recent years, that growth in audience hasn't been reflected in a similar growth in mobile advertising. What we've done by acquiring companies like Unruly and Storyful is to bring real mobile video expertise into News Corporation, not just at The Wall Street Journal, but across the company. And so that is enabling us to derive higher returns and set us on a track for longer-term exploitation of obviously what is going to be a commercially crucial canvas.

headline: News Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: We'll move next to Doug Arthur with Huber Research.
componenttext: We'll move next to Doug Arthur with Huber Research.

headline: News Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just a question on HarperCollins and Book Publishing. And you've had a number of tough comp quarters here with Divergent. How do you sort of see the pipeline and comps going forward?
componenttext: Just a question on HarperCollins and Book Publishing. And you've had a number of tough comp quarters here with Divergent. How do you sort of see the pipeline and comps going forward?

headline: News Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I think with Divergent, the next quarter, we should see some easing of the comps, even though Divergent will still -- I think, pretty late for Q2. So I think that's probably the way to look at it. Obviously, the mix of books, any quarter compared to
componenttext: Well, I think with Divergent, the next quarter, we should see some easing of the comps, even though Divergent will still -- I think, pretty late for Q2. So I think that's probably the way to look at it. Obviously, the mix of books, any quarter compared to the prior quarter, it sort of like depends on what happens. So I think it is one of those businesses that we will continue to grow quarter-by-quarter. But generally, we're very pleased with the way the book business is developing, I think obviously, we'll see how the Christmas selling season pans out.

headline: News Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just to be more specific, clearly, we had a great hit with American Sniper this time last year and into the new year. But just to give you a range of figures that highlight the difficulty of comparison, which is a great challenge for the team at HarperCol
componenttext: Just to be more specific, clearly, we had a great hit with American Sniper this time last year and into the new year. But just to give you a range of figures that highlight the difficulty of comparison, which is a great challenge for the team at HarperCollins, last year in the first quarter, Divergent generated about $25 million in revenue, off about 3.7 million units. In the just completed quarter it was $2 million, of 400,000 net units. And also, don't forget about 40% of those units were e-books, which are a higher margins. So that gives you a sense of why the comps were so complicated.

headline: News Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: We'll take our next question from Justin Diddams with Citi.
componenttext: We'll take our next question from Justin Diddams with Citi.

headline: News Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just a question on Move. Impressive revenue growth for the quarter. I was wondering if you'd just elaborate a little on where that growth's coming from, whether it's sort of increased volume in usage through the platform, whether you put price increases t
componenttext: Just a question on Move. Impressive revenue growth for the quarter. I was wondering if you'd just elaborate a little on where that growth's coming from, whether it's sort of increased volume in usage through the platform, whether you put price increases through on the co-broke product and how you're driving that revenue growth. That would be really useful.

headline: News Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, it's 2 things, I think, to highlight. First of all, it's not any increase in the quantity traffic. It's very high-quality traffic. And that's leading to, in particular, in the co-broke area, an increase in revenue that's quite significant. I think o
componenttext: Well, it's 2 things, I think, to highlight. First of all, it's not any increase in the quantity traffic. It's very high-quality traffic. And that's leading to, in particular, in the co-broke area, an increase in revenue that's quite significant. I think overall revenue rose 33%. You might have noticed early this week, a company that starts the final letter of the alphabet, Z, that is zed, elsewhere, was up 13%. And one other important component was media advertising, which is where the -- not only in the editorial content, but also in the approach to media advertising, we saw a significant increase. That was up 60% year-on-year. And so both of those components have made material improvement.

headline: News Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: We'll take our next question from Andrew Levy with Macquarie.
componenttext: We'll take our next question from Andrew Levy with Macquarie.

headline: News Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just a question on the book segment. You mentioned that the industry trends are a bit weaker for e-book sales. I just want to get your thoughts on what might have been driving that, whether it was related to releases, or you think there's some other indus
componenttext: Just a question on the book segment. You mentioned that the industry trends are a bit weaker for e-book sales. I just want to get your thoughts on what might have been driving that, whether it was related to releases, or you think there's some other industry issues at play at the moment.

headline: News Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Andrew. Yes, I mean, it's sort of hard to tell in sort of precise detail. But I think it's obviously a mix of books will affect that. I think pricing can be a factor in that. So I think there are a number of things at play. But generally, if you r
componenttext: Thanks, Andrew. Yes, I mean, it's sort of hard to tell in sort of precise detail. But I think it's obviously a mix of books will affect that. I think pricing can be a factor in that. So I think there are a number of things at play. But generally, if you read the other book companies and what they've been publishing in terms of their results, I think there seems to be sort of general weakness in e-books.

headline: News Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: And to add to Bedi's point, which is obviously correct, made particularly so in our case because of the Divergent effect and its pronounced e-book component.
componenttext: And to add to Bedi's point, which is obviously correct, made particularly so in our case because of the Divergent effect and its pronounced e-book component.

headline: News Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: We'll take our next question from Craig Huber with Huber Research.
componenttext: We'll take our next question from Craig Huber with Huber Research.

headline: News Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: I was just curious how much thought you guys have given and your Board of Directors has given to potentially breaking up the company by either spinning off your News and Information segment to a separate standalone public company or taking your entire Aus
componenttext: I was just curious how much thought you guys have given and your Board of Directors has given to potentially breaking up the company by either spinning off your News and Information segment to a separate standalone public company or taking your entire Australian assets and spinning those off into a separate Australian equity [sic][entity].

headline: News Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Craig, I think one thing you will have noticed from the results, is how the complementarity of our assets has created a powerful platform. That it makes News Corp as it is far more than a sum of the parts. We couldn't have done what the team have done at
componenttext: Craig, I think one thing you will have noticed from the results, is how the complementarity of our assets has created a powerful platform. That it makes News Corp as it is far more than a sum of the parts. We couldn't have done what the team have done at Realtor without the newspaper assets. We couldn't have done what the team have done at REA without those newspaper assets. And you're seeing that complementarity play out in other ways. And as we get more and more data across the businesses, whether they be the newspaper businesses, the News America Marketing or the real estate companies, we'll be able to share important demographic data. And I think that does give us a real comparative advantage. And what you're seeing at the moment in the ad market, as I mentioned in my preamble, at the moment, there is a lot of tension between advertisers and agencies. And that's both in, for example, freestanding inserts area right across the paper advertising. And we genuinely believe that the asset mix we have is -- has created a platform for the future for the company and, obviously, for shareholders.

headline: News Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: We'll take our next question from Brian Han with Morningstar.
componenttext: We'll take our next question from Brian Han with Morningstar.

headline: News Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Bedi, can you confirm, did you say the earnings and cash flow benefits of divesting Amplify won't come through until fiscal '17? And how much did Amplify cost News Corp in cash burn in '15?
componenttext: Bedi, can you confirm, did you say the earnings and cash flow benefits of divesting Amplify won't come through until fiscal '17? And how much did Amplify cost News Corp in cash burn in '15?

headline: News Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: So in '15, the cash burn was roughly about $200 million. There will be some benefit in fiscal '16. But what I meant was like the full effect will be felt from fiscal '17 onwards.
componenttext: So in '15, the cash burn was roughly about $200 million. There will be some benefit in fiscal '16. But what I meant was like the full effect will be felt from fiscal '17 onwards.

headline: News Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: We'll take our next question from Alice Bennett with CBA.
componenttext: We'll take our next question from Alice Bennett with CBA.

headline: News Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: I just had a question about data which you're referencing quite a lot. Just wondering whether you're close to the point where data is becoming monetizable, I guess. One of your competitors in Australia has talked recently about programmatic finally turnin
componenttext: I just had a question about data which you're referencing quite a lot. Just wondering whether you're close to the point where data is becoming monetizable, I guess. One of your competitors in Australia has talked recently about programmatic finally turning positive the yields for their online display revenues, because of their data and what they're doing with it. Are you at the point where you're close to monetizing it? Or is that more just sharing it with other parts of your business?

headline: News Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Alice, we're certainly monetizing it. And obviously, there's data and there's data. And there's high-quality and there's low grade. And you look, for example, one of the Checkout 51's benefits for the company, and its efficacy is clear, is that instead of
componenttext: Alice, we're certainly monetizing it. And obviously, there's data and there's data. And there's high-quality and there's low grade. And you look, for example, one of the Checkout 51's benefits for the company, and its efficacy is clear, is that instead of intentions or context, through the uploading receipts, you're seeing buying actions.  So that tells you a lot about, not only the purchase, but the purchaser. So for example, if somebody goes to a home improvement store and buys 15 tins of paint, some siding for the house, that person may be preparing that particular home for sale. That lead is invaluable to a realtor. And so at the same time if that person is moving into an area or leaving an area that's -- what you might call a typical catchment area for a Wall Street Journal reader, it's an opportunity to attract a new subscriber. Now that's -- internally, our ability to optimize that data, and clearly, we'll get more sophisticated as the months progress. However, were also able to use that data for our clients, our advertisers and our partners.

headline: News Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: We'll move next to Eric Katz with Wells Fargo.
componenttext: We'll move next to Eric Katz with Wells Fargo.

headline: News Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: So I assume you're consolidating iproperty into your financials in calendar Q1, is you mentioned. Can you tell us the size, how much revenue and EBITDA does that business generate?
componenttext: So I assume you're consolidating iproperty into your financials in calendar Q1, is you mentioned. Can you tell us the size, how much revenue and EBITDA does that business generate?

headline: News Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: So we will be consolidating -- I mean, REA will be consolidating iProperty. And obviously, since we consolidate REA, it will flow upwards into our consolidation. EBITDA from that business is sort of marginal, and our revenues are sort of in the $50 millio
componenttext: So we will be consolidating -- I mean, REA will be consolidating iProperty. And obviously, since we consolidate REA, it will flow upwards into our consolidation. EBITDA from that business is sort of marginal, and our revenues are sort of in the $50 million range.

headline: News Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] And we'll take our next question from Alice Bennett with CBA.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] And we'll take our next question from Alice Bennett with CBA.

headline: News Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just one more question. Just with subscription revenues around the world, it's provided a bit of a buffer to your newspaper revenues for the last couple of years. Just wondering, with the cover price increases that have been fairly aggressive, where do yo
componenttext: Just one more question. Just with subscription revenues around the world, it's provided a bit of a buffer to your newspaper revenues for the last couple of years. Just wondering, with the cover price increases that have been fairly aggressive, where do you see that kind of tapering out over the next year or so? Or will you still see further scope for those to continue to rise?

headline: News Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Alice, I think I wouldn't agree with your phrase aggressive or -- I think we've been conscious of our different markets and the elasticity that different products have. And if you're talking about The Wall Street Journal and the Times of London, that's ve
componenttext: Alice, I think I wouldn't agree with your phrase aggressive or -- I think we've been conscious of our different markets and the elasticity that different products have. And if you're talking about The Wall Street Journal and the Times of London, that's very different to the Daily Telegraph. And -- But at the same time, we believe that these are beacon brands, that they're the best journalism in the world and there is -- remains a certain elasticity, which varies by segment.

headline: News Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Entcho Raykovski with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: We'll go next to Entcho Raykovski with Deutsche Bank.

headline: News Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just a follow-up question around Cable Network Programming. And obviously, there was news earlier this week that the EPL contract has been lost to another provider. I just wanted to understand, how do you think, now internally, about potential loss of sub
componenttext: Just a follow-up question around Cable Network Programming. And obviously, there was news earlier this week that the EPL contract has been lost to another provider. I just wanted to understand, how do you think, now internally, about potential loss of subscribers given that contract is gone? And do you intend to backfill perhaps that spot with either direct agreements with the clubs or other sports?

headline: News Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Entcho, obviously, you can buy any right as long as you're prepared to pay any price. But sometimes by our reckoning, any price is not appropriate for us or our shareholders. And as you say, there are some EPL fans in Australia, there's no doubt about tha
componenttext: Entcho, obviously, you can buy any right as long as you're prepared to pay any price. But sometimes by our reckoning, any price is not appropriate for us or our shareholders. And as you say, there are some EPL fans in Australia, there's no doubt about that, but we're certainly not talking about prime time. The 3 p.m. kickoff in U.K. is 2 a.m. in Australia. So as you know, hard-core fans of anything in Australia are called tragics. So the sweet spot for EPL at 2 in the morning, tragics same insomniacs. And the other thing you might have noticed yesterday, Bayern Munich beat Arsenal, 5-1 in the Champions League, which may be itself an indictment of the value of the Premier League.

headline: News Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: We'll take our final question from Peter Stamoulis with Evans and Partners.
componenttext: We'll take our final question from Peter Stamoulis with Evans and Partners.

headline: News Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: I was just interested in your thoughts around this ad blocking technology and how it may impact your traditional mastheads, and in particular, advertising revenues going forward and how I suppose you mitigate those risks.
componenttext: I was just interested in your thoughts around this ad blocking technology and how it may impact your traditional mastheads, and in particular, advertising revenues going forward and how I suppose you mitigate those risks.

headline: News Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, it's much talked about and less seen, to be honest, in our businesses. The truth is that, for example, Unruly will give us expertise in -- around ads and insight into the use of ads that is valuable to our clients and as well as to our products. But
componenttext: Well, it's much talked about and less seen, to be honest, in our businesses. The truth is that, for example, Unruly will give us expertise in -- around ads and insight into the use of ads that is valuable to our clients and as well as to our products. But the role of ad blockers is much more pronounced in what you might call commodity-content sites, sites that have more noise than use. And that's certainly not ours.

headline: News Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Peter. Well, thank you all for participating, and have a great day. And we'll talk to you next quarter.
componenttext: Thank you, Peter. Well, thank you all for participating, and have a great day. And we'll talk to you next quarter.

headline: News Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 05, 2015
componenttextpreview: That does conclude today's conference. Thank you for your participation.
componenttext: That does conclude today's conference. Thank you for your participation.
